trans-unit.source: Command-line build for Azure
trans-unit.target: Command-line build for Azure

trans-unit.source: Command-line build for Azure
trans-unit.target: Command-line build for Azure

trans-unit.source: Command-Line Build for Azure
trans-unit.target: Command-Line Build for Azure

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: You can create a package for Azure deployment by running MSBuild at a command prompt.
trans-unit.target: You can create a package for Azure deployment by running MSBuild at a command prompt.

trans-unit.source: You can configure and define builds for debugging, staging, and production, in addition to automating some of the build process.
trans-unit.target: You can configure and define builds for debugging, staging, and production, in addition to automating some of the build process.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Build Engine (MSBuild)
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Build Engine (MSBuild)

trans-unit.source: By using the Microsoft Build Engine (MSBuild), you can build products in build lab environments where Visual Studio isn't installed.
trans-unit.target: By using the Microsoft Build Engine (MSBuild), you can build products in build lab environments where Visual Studio isn't installed.

trans-unit.source: MSBuild uses an XML format for project files that's extensible and fully supported by Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: MSBuild uses an XML format for project files that's extensible and fully supported by Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: In this file format, you can describe what items must be built for one or more platforms and configurations.
trans-unit.target: In this file format, you can describe what items must be built for one or more platforms and configurations.

trans-unit.source: You can also run MSBuild at a command prompt, and this topic describes that approach.
trans-unit.target: You can also run MSBuild at a command prompt, and this topic describes that approach.

trans-unit.source: By setting properties at a command prompt, you can build specific configurations of a project.
trans-unit.target: By setting properties at a command prompt, you can build specific configurations of a project.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, you can also define the targets that the MSBuild command will build.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, you can also define the targets that the MSBuild command will build.

trans-unit.source: For more information about command-line parameters and MSBuild, see <link><linkText>MSBuild Command Line Reference</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about command-line parameters and MSBuild, see <link><linkText>MSBuild Command Line Reference</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Installation
trans-unit.target: Installation

trans-unit.source: As the following procedure describes, you must install software and tools on the build server before you can create an Azure package by using MSBuild:
trans-unit.target: As the following procedure describes, you must install software and tools on the build server before you can create an Azure package by using MSBuild:

trans-unit.source: Install the .NET Framework 4 or later, which includes MSBuild.
trans-unit.target: Install the .NET Framework 4 or later, which includes MSBuild.

trans-unit.source: Install the <link><linkText>Azure Authoring Tools</linkText><title></title></link> (look for MicrosoftAzureAuthoringTools-x64.msi or MicrosoftAzureAuthoringTools-x86.msi.
trans-unit.target: Install the <link><linkText>Azure Authoring Tools</linkText><title></title></link> (look for MicrosoftAzureAuthoringTools-x64.msi or MicrosoftAzureAuthoringTools-x86.msi.

trans-unit.source: Install the <link><linkText>Azure Libraries for .NET</linkText><title></title></link> (look for MicrosoftAzureLibsForNet-x64.msi or MicrosoftAzureLibs-x86.msi.
trans-unit.target: Install the <link><linkText>Azure Libraries for .NET</linkText><title></title></link> (look for MicrosoftAzureLibsForNet-x64.msi or MicrosoftAzureLibs-x86.msi.

trans-unit.source: Copy the Microsoft.WebApplication.targets file from a Visual Studio installation on another computer.
trans-unit.target: Copy the Microsoft.WebApplication.targets file from a Visual Studio installation on another computer.

trans-unit.source: The file is located in the directory C:\Program Files (x86)\MSBuild\Microsoft\Visual Studio\v12.0\WebApplications (v11.0 for Visual Studio 2012), and you should copy it to the same directory on the build server.
trans-unit.target: The file is located in the directory C:\Program Files (x86)\MSBuild\Microsoft\Visual Studio\v12.0\WebApplications (v11.0 for Visual Studio 2012), and you should copy it to the same directory on the build server.

trans-unit.source: Install the <link><linkText>Azure Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Install the <link><linkText>Azure Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Look for WindowsAzureTools.vs120.exe to build Visual Studio 2013 projects.
trans-unit.target: Look for WindowsAzureTools.vs120.exe to build Visual Studio 2013 projects.

trans-unit.source: MSBuild Parameters
trans-unit.target: MSBuild Parameters

trans-unit.source: The simplest way to create a package is to run MSBuild with the /t:Publish option.
trans-unit.target: The simplest way to create a package is to run MSBuild with the /t:Publish option.

trans-unit.source: By default, this command creates a directory in relation to the root folder for the project, such as ProjectDir\bin\Configuration\app.publish\.
trans-unit.target: By default, this command creates a directory in relation to the root folder for the project, such as ProjectDir\bin\Configuration\app.publish\.

trans-unit.source: When you build an Azure project, you generate two files, the package file itself and the accompanying configuration file:
trans-unit.target: When you build an Azure project, you generate two files, the package file itself and the accompanying configuration file:

trans-unit.source: Project.cspkg
trans-unit.target: Project.cspkg

trans-unit.source: ServiceConfiguration.TargetProfile.cscfg
trans-unit.target: ServiceConfiguration.TargetProfile.cscfg

trans-unit.source: By default, each Azure project includes one service-configuration file for local (debugging) builds and another for cloud (staging or production) builds, but you can add or remove service-configuration files as needed.
trans-unit.target: By default, each Azure project includes one service-configuration file for local (debugging) builds and another for cloud (staging or production) builds, but you can add or remove service-configuration files as needed.

trans-unit.source: When you build a package within Visual Studio, you will be asked which service-configuration file to include alongside the package.
trans-unit.target: When you build a package within Visual Studio, you will be asked which service-configuration file to include alongside the package.

trans-unit.source: When you build a package by using MSBuild, the local service-configuration file is included by default.
trans-unit.target: When you build a package by using MSBuild, the local service-configuration file is included by default.

trans-unit.source: To include a different service-configuration file, set the TargetProfile property of the MSBuild command (MSBuild /t:Publish /p:TargetProfile=ProfileName).
trans-unit.target: To include a different service-configuration file, set the TargetProfile property of the MSBuild command (MSBuild /t:Publish /p:TargetProfile=ProfileName).

trans-unit.source: If you want to use an alternate directory for the stored package and configuration files, set the path by using the /p:PublishDir=Directory\ option, including the trailing backslash separator.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use an alternate directory for the stored package and configuration files, set the path by using the /p:PublishDir=Directory\ option, including the trailing backslash separator.

trans-unit.source: Deployment
trans-unit.target: Deployment

trans-unit.source: After the package is built, you can deploy it to Azure.
trans-unit.target: After the package is built, you can deploy it to Azure.

trans-unit.source: For a tutorial that demonstrates that process, see the Azure website.
trans-unit.target: For a tutorial that demonstrates that process, see the Azure website.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to automate that process, see <link><linkText>Continuous Delivery for Cloud Services in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to automate that process, see <link><linkText>Continuous Delivery for Cloud Services in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
